To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com Contributors Opinion More action urgently needed to ensure no one is left behind in COVID-19 crisis KL By Katherine Lippel Thu., March 19, 2020timer3 min. read updateArticle was updated Mar. 30, 2020 On the heels of the COVID-19 crisis, the federal government has now improved access to Employment Insurance and some provinces, but not all, have discouraged employers from requiring sick notes. Banks have offered a six month payment deferral for mortgages and organizations responsible for workers' compensation and occupational health and safety in some provinces have produced timely guidance material. Much more needs to be done. Little if any action has been taken to relieve the needs of tenants who can't meet their rental payments. No one in Canada, including the precariously employed, should be left homeless or destitute because of COVID-19 and the consequences it will have for both the health of our people and our economy. We must ensure that workers have the ability to stop working if they are ill, in their own interest and in the interest of public health. Statistics Canada estimates that between 27 per cent and 45 per cent of all Canadian workers do not have full-time stable jobs. This does not include low wage earners with full-time stable jobs who still live from paycheque to paycheque. The precariously employed include: the solo self-employed including those working in the gig economy; those on temporary contracts, working on call or for temporary employment agencies; and part-time workers, including the involuntary part time. In many provinces, full-time, low-wage earners are also in situations of employment precarity where employers may lay them off at will or where non-unionized workers can be fired for being absent for more than three days, even if they are absent because of illness. Labour legislation does not discourage employers from requiring sick notes to justify absences. Bill 148 in Ontario had curtailed employers' right to require sick notes, but that provision was repealed by the Ford government's Making Ontario Open for Business Bill 47. Now, we've heard promises that legislation is in the works that will ensure employers no longer require sickness notes in Ontario for those in quarantine, although the legislation has yet to be tabled. Anyone can be at risk of contracting COVID-19 at work, but workers in certain sectors, such as health care and also those working with the public, are particularly at risk. Occupational Health and Safety legislation requires that employers protect workers from hazards and workers have the right to refuse work that endangers their health. Health and safety regulators and public health officials are mandated to proactively provide guidance to workers on the front lines to protect their health and safety and that of others. If workers do become ill out of and in the course of their employment, workers' compensation should normally be provided. Compensation boards need to adapt their requirements of all injured workers in light of current challenges to the health care system. Lots of workers will be falling through the cracks of a very uneven social safety net in Canada, primarily provincially regulated with regard to labour legislation, and federally regulated, with regard to Employment Insurance. In other words, it is highly likely that some workers will not be able to pay their rent or feed their families if the current crisis is to go on for weeks or even months. Our governments need to take more action. Legislation improving Labour Standards and Workers' Compensation coverage is required to ensure that all workers who are absent because of illness or in quarantine should be guaranteed economic support while they are away, regardless of their contractual status. They should not be required to produce sick notes by their employers and they should be protected from reprisals if they are absent for health reasons. New measures should be introduced to protect the jobs of workers who are unable to work because of COVID-19. Provinces should enact temporary prohibition of evictions for nonpayment of rent. It sometimes takes a crisis to reveal all the fault lines in our flawed social safety nets. We can weather the difficulties arising from COVID-19, but only if we face it together and make sure to leave no one in Canada behind. Katherine Lippel is the Distinguished Research Chair in Occupational Health and Safety Law and a member of the Centre for Health Law, Policy and Ethics at the University of Ottawa. To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com Ontario Province halts new evictions, postpones scheduled orders due to COVID-19 By May WarrenStaff Reporter Toronto Star Mon., March 16, 2020timer1 min. read updateArticle was updated Mar. 18, 2020 No new eviction orders will be issued until further notice in Ontario due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Ministry of the Attorney General spokesperson Jesse Robichaud confirmed the news in an email to the Star Monday evening. "In addition, Sheriff's offices have been asked to postpone any scheduled enforcement of eviction orders currently set for this week," she added. The news comes as tenant advocates pushed for the province to freeze evictions, a move that several U.S. cities, including New York and San Francisco, have already made. Freelance illustrator and artist Paterson Hodgson called it "a no-brainer" and said she'd also like to see a rent freeze. She said there's a lot of worry amongst the neighbours in her highrise building. Many are facing reduced hours if not layoffs, as well as the "financial burden" of stocking up for possible self-isolation. "The idea that someone could have no home during these very unsure times is very scary," she said, in an interview before the decision. Parkdale legal clinic worker Cole Webber joined legal clinic workers, lawyers and other advocates in the city in sending a letter to the Ministry of the Attorney General and the executive chair of Tribunals Ontario on Sunday calling for an immediate eviction freeze "in the midst of a pandemic." It was not immediately clear how long scheduled enforcement of eviction orders would be postponed for. Benjamin Ries, a lawyer and member of the Greater Toronto Clinic Housing Advocates, who signed off on the letter, said in an interview before the decision was made that there is firstly a "fairness issue, with people losing income for reasons that are entirely beyond their control." But there's also a public health reason to stop evictions. There's "overwhelming evidence" that homelessness, even temporarily, leads to an increase in emergency room visits and hospitalization, and there's also some evidence it can lead to incarceration, Ries said. May Warren is a breaking news reporter based in Toronto. To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com Editorial Editorial: Border closures a temporary, not lasting solution Fri., March 20, 2020timer3 min. read updateArticle was updated Mar. 30, 2020 In the coming hours, Canadians will see something that would have been unimaginable mere days ago. They will witness the closing of the world's longest border, the one separating their country from the United States, to all but economically essential travel. As extreme a measure as it may seem, the governments of both countries were correct to adopt it because it will limit the spread of COVID-19, which has already claimed 10,000 lives around the world. Desperate times justify desperate actions. And Ottawa was also right to ban travel into Canada from everywhere else in the world, except for the citizens and permanent residents of this country returning home. But while Canadians can applaud the federal government for taking these protective steps, they should hope that such wide-ranging restrictions, which are now in place in 91 countries, do not outlast the pandemic itself. That, unfortunately, is not a given. Across the political spectrum, critics of open borders and the free movement of goods and services are wrongly blaming globalization for COVID-19 and its fallout. Donald Trump and his right-wing, populist supporters claim the pandemic proves borders must be tightened to keep out foreigners and "foreign" illnesses â which is how the American president wrongly refers to COVID-19. At the same time, some left-of-centre critics of capitalism argue the pandemic's disruption of supply chains and its contribution to an impending global recession demonstrate the need for drastic economic reforms. They advocate reverting to the more locally oriented â and far poorer â markets of bygone days. The critics on both sides are wrong. We do not need more xenophobic walls or protectionist barriers in this world. Globalization should not become another casualty of COVID-19, and Canadians, of all people, should realize this. Canada is a trading country with a third of its wealth coming from its exports. Since the late 20th century, as Canada forged new trading alliances with the U.S., then Mexico and later both the European Union and a host of Pacific Rim counties, this country has prospered as never before. Canada is a country of immigrants that has been built over centuries and continues to be built today by newcomers from around the planet. In addition, Canada is a nation of travelers, with an estimated three million of its citizens now living abroad. Thanks to the open â but managed â borders that allow both immigrants into Canada and Canadians into other countries, Canada is enriched by a steady flow of new ideas, new innovations and new connections. And as Canada has joined the movement to open international borders elsewhere, hundreds of millions of people around the world have benefitted. While the World Bank estimates that 44 per cent of humans lived in extreme poverty as recently as 1981, that number had fallen to 8.6 per cent by 2018. The sharp increase in international trade and global migration contributed to this remarkable progress. We know this pandemic is as unsettling as it is frightening. When the world has put this crisis behind it â as it will â there will be time for reflection, review and necessary changes to reduce the odds of a future pandemic that is so debilitating. But this is not the time for misdiagnosis. We should remember that centuries before the era of globalization, jet travel and modern supply chains, the world was repeatedly ravaged by epidemics of bubonic plague, smallpox and influenza. Closed borders, closed economies and closed minds aren't the cure to what ails humanity. International co-operation and the eventual return to a more open world are. To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com Contributors Opinion Whether you're working or not, here's why your employer should keep paying you through the COVID-19 outbreak By Heather ScoffieldEconomics Columnist Toronto Star Thu., March 19, 2020timer3 min. read updateArticle was updated Mar. 30, 2020 Banks offering to restructure mortgage payments. Telcos giving their customers unlimited data. Chicken farmers making large donations to local food banks. Airlines providing free flights back to Canada. Examples of corporate benevolence, if we can call it that, are showing up everywhere in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. More of this please. It's easy to get dragged down by stories about unscrupulous behaviour - the price-gougers, the employers who demand that workers show up, the malls that won't shut down or the workplaces that are just careless about social distancing. But, anecdotally at least, examples of benevolent measures by employers seem to outweigh the nasty. So where should corporate leaders who want to help Canada get through this focus their energy? Economic policy-makers are freeing up billions of dollars to bridge the coronavirus economy for Canada's deeply troubled business sectors and the people who work in them. CEOs should make that public money work even more effectively by thinking hard about how to help underwrite a collapsing workforce. Their efforts need not be driven by altruism alone. If they don't want to wait for years to see a reasonably functioning economy when this is all over, there are compelling business reasons to take some responsibility and help shoulder the burden now. The federally regulated sectors of the economy seem already to understand this. Commercial banks are showing welcome flexibility by opening the doors to their indebted customers and renegotiating loans and mortgages if need be, formally committing to leniency on a case-by-case basis. The telecommunications companies and the airlines are helping out, too - telcos by allowing unlimited data to encourage working from home, and airlines by flying half-empty planes to bring Canadians back home from abroad. (Sunwing even offered free seats on Thursday.) Both of those industries benefit from federal regulation, and it's part of the bargain. The country helps them all the time; they need to help us right now. "This is reciprocity," said economist Jim Stanford. But there will need to be a lot more of this kind of thinking if we have any hope of a speedy economic recovery when this crisis finally ends. It's in corporate Canada's best interest to figure out ways to keep workers on the payroll, even if there's no revenue coming in, says Goldy Hyder, president of the Business Council of Canada. That's because there was a labour shortage before coronavirus brought many businesses to a standstill, and it's fair to expect that it will return when the pandemic is over. Failing that, corporations need to lay off workers cleanly so that they can quickly qualify for Employment Insurance, says David Macdonald, senior economist with the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives. That's what Noront Resources did for its workforce of 20 mainly Indigenous workers in remote northern Ontario, says vice-president Glenn Nolan. Knowing the workers were susceptible to contagion because they often come from overcrowded communities with weak health care systems, the company laid them off, sent them home with severance and promised to call them back when the virus has calmed down. The top corporate responsibility, however, is staving off bankruptcy in whatever way possible. A company that closes its doors can't simply come back to life when the crisis abates. But keeping those doors open will be easier said than done. Revenues have dropped off a cliff in the hospitality, airline, tourism, oil and gas, and retail sectors, and we are in deep trouble in manufacturing and exports. Corporate goodwill will be necessary to getting through this, but it won't be enough. As Stanford noted, "It's not going to be charity that saves us here. It's going to be government intervention and planning." Heather Scoffield is the Star's Ottawa bureau chief and an economics columnist.
